perturbation.original_text: Provider shall submit or cause to be submitted to Recipient in writing, within 15 days after the end of each month, an invoice setting forth the Fees for the Services provided to Recipient during such month in reasonable detail, as applicable, due under such invoice.
perturbation.changed_text: Provider shall submit or cause to be submitted to Recipient in writing, within 45 days after the end of each month, an invoice setting forth the Fees for the Services provided to Recipient during such month in reasonable detail, as applicable, due under such invoice.
perturbation.explanation: By extending the invoicing period to 45 days, the contract contradicts standard business practices and potentially conflicts with state prompt payment laws, which often mandate shorter invoicing cycles, especially for specific industries or government contracts. This creates uncertainty and could be deemed an unreasonable delay in payment processing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws (e.g., for government contracts or specific industries)

perturbation.original_text: Recipient shall pay, or cause to be paid, the Fees shown on an invoice no later than the last business day of the month Recipient received such invoice unless disputed in accordance with Section 5.7. Any amount not received from the invoiced Party within such period shall bear interest at the Applicable Rate, from and including the last date of such period to, but excluding, the date of payment.
perturbation.changed_text: Recipient shall pay, or cause to be paid, the Fees shown on an invoice no later than 90 days after the end of the month Recipient received such invoice unless disputed in accordance with Section 5.7. Any amount not received from the invoiced Party within such period shall bear interest at one percent (1%), from and including the last date of such period to, but excluding, the date of payment.
perturbation.explanation: By extending the payment period to 90 days, the contract might conflict with state laws regarding payment terms, particularly if they mandate shorter payment cycles for services rendered. Furthermore, setting the interest rate at one percent (1%) may contradict state usury laws if it is deemed excessively low and not reflective of the actual cost of delayed payment, making the term potentially unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Usury Laws and Prompt Payment Laws

perturbation.original_text:
This Agreement shall terminate when the Termination Date has occurred for all Services. In addition, this Agreement may be terminated by either Party (the “Terminating Party”) upon written notice to the other Party (which notice, in case of material breach, shall specify the basis for such claim for breach), if:
(a) the other Party or its Affiliates materially breaches this Agreement and such breach is not cured, to the reasonable satisfaction of the Terminating Party, within thirty (30) days of written notice thereof, it being understood that a good-faith dispute over an invoice or Service shall not constitute a material breach of this Agreement; or
(b) the other Party files for bankruptcy or similar proceeding, is the subject of an involuntary filing for bankruptcy or similar proceeding (not dismissed within sixty (60) days), makes a general assignment of all or substantially all of its assets for the benefit of creditors, becomes or is declared insolvent, becomes the subject of any proceedings (not dismissed within sixty (60) days) related to its liquidation, insolvency, bankruptcy or the appointment of a trustee or a receiver, takes any corporate action for its winding up or dissolution, or a court approves reorganization proceedings on such Party.
perturbation.changed_text:
This Agreement shall terminate when the Termination Date has occurred for all Services. In addition, this Agreement may be terminated by either Party (the “Terminating Party”) upon written notice to the other Party (which notice, in case of material breach, shall specify the basis for such claim for breach), if:
(a) the other Party or its Affiliates materially breaches this Agreement and such breach is not cured, to the reasonable satisfaction of the Terminating Party, within ten (10) days of written notice thereof, it being understood that a good-faith dispute over an invoice or Service shall not constitute a material breach of this Agreement; or
(b) the other Party files for bankruptcy or similar proceeding, is the subject of an involuntary filing for bankruptcy or similar proceeding (not dismissed within thirty (30) days), makes a general assignment of all or substantially all of its assets for the benefit of creditors, becomes or is declared insolvent, becomes the subject of any proceedings (not dismissed within thirty (30) days) related to its liquidation, insolvency, bankruptcy or the appointment of a trustee or a receiver, takes any corporate action for its winding up or dissolution, or a court approves reorganization proceedings on such Party.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach to ten (10) days and reducing the dismissal period for involuntary bankruptcy to thirty (30) days could be considered unreasonably short, potentially conflicting with principles of fairness and good faith implied in contract law. Courts often look unfavorably on contract terms that provide insufficient time for parties to remedy breaches or address serious financial issues, potentially rendering these terms unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing in Contract Law
